Authors: Zuo S., Yang J., Liu J., Cai X.
Title: Significance of the carbonization of volatile pyrolytic products on the properties of activated carbons from phosphoric acid activation of lignocellulosic material
Affiliations: Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, 210037, China; Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, CAF, Nanjing, 210042, China
Authors with affiliations: Zuo, S., Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, 210037, China; Yang, J., Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, 210037, China; Liu, J., Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, CAF, Nanjing, 210042, China; Cai, X., Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, 210037, China
Abstract: Two series of activated carbons derived from China fir (Cunninghamia lanceolata) wood impregnated with phosphoric acid were prepared in a cylindrical container that was kept in a closed state covered with a lid (the covered case) or in an open state. The effects of the carbonization of volatile pyrolytic products of starting materials on the properties of activated carbon were investigated in the process of phosphoric acid activation. Elemental analysis and SEM observation showed that both activating in the covered case and increasing the mass of starting material used favored the carbonization of volatile pyrolytic products. An investigation of N2 adsorption isotherms revealed that the carbonization of volatile pyrolytic products significantly enhanced mesopore development in the final carbons, especially pores with a size range from 2.5 to 30 nm, with little influence on micropores, and therefore produced a large increase in the adsorption capacity to Vitamin B12 (with a molecular size of 2.09 nm). Activated carbons with highly developed mesopores could be obtained in the covered case. The carbonization mechanism of volatiles was discussed and two different carbonization pathways (in solid and gas phases) were proposed during phosphoric acid activation. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Zverev V.E.
Title: Mortality and recruitment of mountain birch (Betula pubescens ssp. czerepanovii) in the impact zone of a copper-nickel smelter in the period of significant reduction of emissions: The results of 15-year monitoring
Affiliations: University of Turku, FI-20014 Turku, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Zverev, V.E., University of Turku, FI-20014 Turku, Finland
Abstract: Long-term monitoring of mountain birch populations (1992-2006) was performed in 14 test plots located at distances of 1 to 63 km from the copper-nickel smelter in Monchegorsk (Murmansk oblast) and differing in the degree of disturbance. In the period from 1999 to 2006, atmospheric emissions of sulfur dioxide and heavy metals amounted to only one-third of those between 1992 and 1998, but birch mortality in heavily polluted areas (with nickel concentrations in leaves exceeding 160 mg/kg) remained at the same level, being absent (as previously) in less polluted areas. Throughout the observation period, birch recruitment was observed only in areas where nickel concentrations in the leaves were below 160 mg/kg; i.e., this concentration proved to be the threshold with respect to both mortality and recruitment of mountain birch. The course of demographic processes in its populations has remained unchanged after the reduction of emissions, confirming the hypothesis of the "inertial" effect of industrial emissions on ecosystems. In some areas of industrial barrens, mountain birch may perish completely within the next decade. © Pleiades Publishing, Ltd., 2009.
Author Keywords: Heavy metals; Industrial pollution; Mortality; Mountain birch; Northern taiga; Recruitment

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of maintenance plan for carbon monoxide; State of Arizona; Tucson air planning area
Abstract: Pursuant to the Clean Air Act, EPA is approving two revisions to the Arizona SIP. These revisions include the 2008 Revision to the CO Limited Maintenance Plan for the Tucson Air Planning Area, submitted on 7/10/2008, and a statutory provision, submitted on 6/22/2009, that extends the life of the State's vehicle emissions inspection program through the end of 2016. EPA is taking this action pursuant to those provisions of the Clean Air Act that obligate the Agency to take action on submittals of revisions to SIP. The effect of this action is to make certain commitments related to maintenance of the CO standard in the Tucson Air Planning Area Federally enforceable as part of the Arizona SIP. This rule is effective on 1/20/2010. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference intergovernmental relations, and reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) and Nonattainment new Source Review (NSR): Inclusion of fugitive emissions; Interim final rule; Stay
Abstract: EPA is making an interim final determination to provide an additional stay of the regulations concerning the inclusion of fugitive emissions. Entities potentially affected by this action include state, local, and tribal governments. Industry groups include petroleum refining, industrial inorganic chemicals, natural gas liquids, etc. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 51 include administrative practices and procedures, air pollution control, CO, fugitive emissions, intergovernmental relation, lead, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, sulfur oxides, transportation, and VOC. Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include administrative practices and procedures, air pollution control, CO, fugitive emissions, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relation, lead, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx, transportation, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Pennsylvania; Clean air interstate rule; NOx SIP call rule; Amendments to NOx control rules
Abstract: In this final rule, EPA is approving a SIP revision from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, which addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) and modifies other requirements in Pennsylvania's SIP that interact with CAIR. These requirements include the termination of Pennsylvania's NOx Budget Trading Program; statewide provisions for large, stationary internal combustion engines; statewide provisions for large cement kilns; provisions for small sources of NOx in the Pennsylvania portion of the Philadelphia 8-hr ozone nonattainment area; and emission reduction credits. CAIR, as promulgated, requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, or interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. EPA is approving the SIP revision as fully implementing the CAIR requirements for Pennsylvania. The final rule takes effect on 12/10/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: European Paper Week focuses on sustainability
Abstract: European Council of Real Estate Professions' (CEPI) 11th European Paper Week was held in Brussels in the month of November 2009. Sustainability was the theme of a series of presentations on issues such as biodiversity, biorefining, water foot-printing and benchmarking for the European Union's emissions trading scheme. Nigel Bagley, director of industry affairs and global customer development at Unilever, presented 15 core indicators being prepared by industry players to create a global harmonized terminology for packaging. Klaus Neumann of Borregaard explained how his own company's biorefinery activities have allowed it not only to produce ethanol for energy generation, but also for applications useful for the food, pharmaceutical, cosmetics and agricultural industries, among many others. Robert Taylor emphasized that the failure of companies in the pulp and paper industry to act to protect biodiversity under their own initiatives entails a good deal of risk.
Index Keywords: Agricultural industries; Biorefineries; Biorefining; Borregaard; Brussels; Energy generations; European council; European union's emissions trading schemes; Pulp and paper industry; Real estate; Unilever; Agriculture; Biodiversity; Ethanol; International law; Sustainable development; Paper and pulp industry; Agriculture; Biodiversity; Ethanol; Paper Industry; Pulp Industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Piedmont to build pipeline, compression facilities for power plant
Abstract: Piedmont Natural Gas finalized an agreement with Progress Energy Carolinas to provide natural gas delivery service to the electric utility's power generation facility to be built at the Wayne County, NC, energy complex. Piedmont will construct 38-mi of 20-in. pipeline along with additional compression to provide natural gas delivery service to the plant by July 2012. Piedmont's investment in the pipeline and compression facilities is estimated at $85 million. The plan for the power plant includes retiring three existing coal-fired units at the adjacent H.F. Lee Plant once the new gas-fueled units come online. Progress Energy Carolinas expects the new combined-cycle natural gas plant will increase the amount of electricity produced at the site while reducing overall emission rates for CO 2 by ≈ 60%, mercury rates by 100%, SO 2 by ∼ 100% and NO x by > 95%.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Carbon tracks beyond paper
Abstract: Verso Paper joined with National Geographic Society, Quad/Graphics, and Harmony Environmental to conduct a comprehensive study of the carbon footprint associated with the publication of National Geographic magazine. The study was titled Carbon Footprint Life Cycle Analysis (LCA). One of Verso's contributions to the carbon footprint LCA study was to share its expertise and methodology developed in 2008 for measuring the carbon footprint of its Advocate 30-lb High Bulk paper manufactured at its Bucksport mill. Verso collaborated with its suppliers in the forestry, transportation and chemical industries from which reliable CO2 emissions data were supplied to the carbon footprint calculations. The protocol for conducting the study followed the Green House Gas (GHG) Protocol Corporate Standard published by the World Resources Institute (WRI) and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD).

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; North Carolina; Clean Air Interstate Rule
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve revisions to the North Carolina SIP submitted by the State of North Carolina through the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources on 6/20/2008. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR). Although the DC Circuit Court found CAIR to be flawed, the rule was remanded without vacatur and thus remains in place. EPA is continuing to approve CAIR provisions into SIP as appropriate. CAIR, as promulgated, requires States to reduce SO2 and NOx emissions that significantly contribute to, or interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or establishes budgets for SO2 and NOx in States that contribute significantly to nonattainment of the NAAQS in downwind States and requires the significantly contributing States to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets. In the SIP revision that EPA is approving, North Carolina has met the CAIR requirements by electing to participate in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions. Consequently, this SIP revision approval will automatically replace and withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans currently in place for North Carolina. The final rule is effective on 11/30/2009.

Authors: Board on Army Science and Technology, Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences, Committee on Disposal of Legacy Nerve Agent GA and Lewisite Stocks at Deseret Chemical Depot, National Research Council
Title: Disposal of legacy nerve agent GA and lewisite stocks at Deseret Chemical Depot: Letter report
Source title: Disposal of Legacy Nerve Agent GA and Lewisite Stocks at Deseret Chemical Depot: Letter Report
Authors with affiliations: Board on Army Science and Technology; Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences; Committee on Disposal of Legacy Nerve Agent GA and Lewisite Stocks at Deseret Chemical Depot; National Research Council
Abstract: The National Research Council of the National Academies established a study committee to assess the disposal of stocks of legacy nerve agent GA and lewisite at Deseret Chemical Depot. Specifically, the Committee on Disposal of Legacy Nerve Agent GA and Lewisite Stocks at Deseret Chemical Depot reviewed information provided to it on the 50 percent design of the Area Ten Liquid Incinerator (ATLIC) facility. The committee focused on differences between the process design being used for the ATLIC facility and those used at the Tooele Chemical Agent Disposal Facility (TOCDF), which has operated successfully for over a decade in campaigns to destroy nerve agents GB and VX and mustard agent. This letter report provides the technical information necessary to support the general and specific findings and recommendations of the committee. This analysis examines the process design and procedural steps to be used for treating GA and lewisite at the Deseret Chemical Depot; provides an assessment of the process design which includes a new incinerator and associated pollution abatement system to be tailored to the requirements for treating the GA and lewisite; and provides an assessment of the process design to determine the system's ability to reduce arsenic and mercury emissions to within the Maximum Achievable Control Technology (MACT) new source regulatory limits. © 2009 National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EPA GHG emission requirements could affect interstate pipelines
Abstract: The EPA's final rule issued on 9/22/2009 on who has to report greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the EPA leaves out the interstate pipeline industry, although it is not clear whether the industry, which had protested its initial inclusion in the proposed rule, is out of the woods entirely or whether the agency is simply refining reporting requirements for pipelines, and will publish them in the near future. The costs of controlling NO x, which is not a GHG, but is the subject of another proposed rule the EPA issued last summer, is expensive, and might parallel the costs of controlling CO 2 and CH 4 emissions. To address a state requirement, an INGAA member was recently required to reduce NO x from existing IC engines for several facilities. At one facility, low emissions combustion NO x control was installed on three larger engines (3400 hp each) with a total capital investment cost of over $3.4 million. When the EPA published its final rule on GHG reporting, it admitted that the pipelines and the oil companies who are in the same category, for purposes of GHG reporting, made some good points. These alternatives will provide similar coverage of vented and fugitive CH 4 and other GHG emissions in the oil and gas sector, while concurrently taking into account industry burden. Where applicable, EPA will also consider the applicability of engineering estimates, emissions modeling software, and emissions factors rather than relying so extensively on the use of direct measurement. EPA will consider optimal methods of data collection in order to maximize data accuracy, while considering industry burden.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The clean energy race: Pew Research Center sees greenhouse gas regulation as all but inevitable
Abstract: Federal Government Outreach for the Pew Research Center on Global Climate Change, US, expects that greenhouse gas regulations are to be implemented in the country. Professionals associated with the research center state such regulations will be implemented by the EPA that has been directed by the Supreme Court of the country to take such measures. Cap and trade will also play a key role in the implementation of such regulations. The regulations will require direct emitters of greenhouse gases to report about such emissions. The cap and trade system will directly apply to large emitters, oil refiners and importers, and large distributors of natural gas. The country will set an annual limit on e total emissions of greenhouse gasses that these various large sources can put into the atmosphere under the system.
Index Keywords: Cap and trade; Clean energy; Federal governments; Global climate changes; Greenhouse gas regulation; Research center; Supreme Court; Total emissions; Environmental Protection Agency; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Greenhouses; Petroleum refining; Research; Laws and legislation

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Renewable force
Abstract: Middle East and North Africa (MENA) countries are finding alternatives for their energy security in the form of renewable energy resources. The United Arab Emirates' (UAE) Masdar, a subsidiary of the Mubadala Development Company, is leading the way by developing a 100 MW concentrated solar power plant, known as SHAMS I. Algeria, Egypt and Morocco are developing Integrated Solar Cycle Combination plants that use solar power to save in fossil fuel-generated power. Two Euro-MENA collaborations, one launched by the Desertec Foundation in Berlin and second known as the Mediterranean Solar Plan, are underway. Funds for these projects could be attracted through investment tax credits and by trading certificates of emission reduction, which were formulated under the Kyoto Clean Development Mechanism. A regional investment plan by the World Bank under the Clean Technology Fund will be formulated with the aim of attracting as much as $750 million to support the Mediterranean Solar Plan.
Index Keywords: alternative energy; clean development mechanism; emission control; energy resource; fossil fuel; Kyoto Protocol; power generation; renewable resource; solar power; World Bank; Algeria; Berlin; Egypt; Germany; Morocco; United Arab Emirates

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EC taps Yorkshire carbon capture & storage project
Abstract: Powerfuel Ltd will receive £164 million in funding for its planned project to establish a 900 Mw power plant with carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology. The integrated coal gasification station would employ a CCS technology that involves liquefying the CO2 emissions created by burning fossil fuels and then pumping them out to depleted gas fields. It would form part of a regional CCS Cluster encompassing power stations that are close to depleted gas fields in the North Sea, where CO2 can be stored. The first phase of the project involves the construction of an 800 Mw combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) facility that will be powered by a natural gas pipeline connection to the National Transmission System, 11 km from the Hatfield site. The power station is due on stream at the end of 2013. In phase 2, Powerfuel plans to convert the CCGT plant into a 900 Mw integrated gasification combined cycle (IGCC) station fuelled by its extensive coal resources at the Hatfield colliery. The CCGT is designed and optimized for "synthesis gas" conversion and operation. Phase 2 is scheduled to be started in the spring of 2011, with completion of the IGCC scheduled for the end of 2015.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: World news: News digest: USA: Reconsidering flexibility
Abstract: The EPA has removed several aspects of Texas' air pollution permitting program, which includes flexible permits that have allowed facilities to exceed toxic emissions on a short term basis, so long as they complied in the long term. The new regulations are due to be instigated in 2010, bringing the state in compliance with the Clean Air Act, as well as improving the local ecology. It is possible that facilities would need to spend millions of dollars upgrading emissions control equipment, costs that may be passed on to consumers as well as affecting other industries that contribute to the Texas economy.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Latin America: Mexico: The World Bank has...
Abstract: The World Bank has approved a $1.5 billion loan for Mexico's urban transport and energy sectors. Specific targets include the implementation of a cross-sector strategy for emissions reductions and the establishment of regulations, monitoring capacity and financing mechanisms to reduce emissions in urban transport, energy generation and efficiency. The project is expected to be completed by May 2011.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, Northern Sierra air quality management district and San Joaquin Valley unified air pollution control district
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of revisions to the Northern Sierra Air Quality Management District and San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portions of the California SIP. These revisions were proposed in the Federal Register on 7/13/2009, and concern VOC emissions from asphalt paving, gasoline bulk storage tanks, and gasoline dispensing stations. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 11/30/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Prevention of significant deterioration and title V greenhouse gas tailoring rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to tailor the major source applicability thresholds for greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions under the Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) and title V programs of the Clean Air Act and to set a PSD significance level for GHG emissions. This proposal is necessary because EPA expects soon to promulgate regulations under the CAA to control GHG emissions and, as a result, trigger PSD and title V applicability requirements for GHG emissions. If PSD and title V requirements apply at the applicability levels provided under the CAA, State permitting authorities would be paralyzed by permit applications in numbers that are orders of magnitude greater than their current administrative resources could accommodate. This proposed rule would phase in the applicability thresholds for both the PSD and title V programs for sources of GHG emissions. The first phase, which would last 6 yr, would establish a temporary level for the PSD and title V applicability thresholds at 25,000 ton/yr, on a CO2 equivalent (CO2e) basis, and a temporary PSD significance level for GHG emissions of between 10,000 and 25,000 ton/yr CO2e. EPA would also take other streamlining actions during this time. Comments must be received on or before 12/28/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR part 51 include administrative practice and procedure, air pollution control, CO2, CO2 equivalents, environmental protection, greenhouse gases, hydrofluorocarbons, intergovernmental relations, methane, nitrous oxide, perfluorocarbons, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and sulfur hexafluoride. Subjects in 40 CFR part 52 include air pollution control, CO2, CO2 equivalents, environmental protection, greenhouse gases, hydrofluorocarbons, intergovernmental relations, methane, nitrous oxide, perfluorocarbons, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, sulfur hexafluoride. Subjects in 40 CFR part 70 include administrative practice and procedure, air pollution control, CO2, CO2 equivalents, environmental protection, greenhouse gases, and hydrofluorocarbons.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State implementation plan, San Joaquin Valley unified air pollution control district
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions were proposed in the Federal Register on 7/13/2009, and concern NOx emissions from stationary gas turbines. EPA is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. This rule is effective on 11/20/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NO2, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; South Carolina; Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve a revision to the South Carolina SIP submitted by the State of South Carolina through the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control on 12/4/2008. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) and the transition of the State's NOx Budget Trading Program to the State's CAIR NOx Ozone Season Program. Although the District of Columbia Circuit Court found CAIR to be flawed, the rule was remanded without vacatur and thus remains in place. Thus, EPA is continuing to approve CAIR provisions into SIP as appropriate. CAIR, as promulgated, requires states to reduce SO2 and NOx emissions that significantly contribute to, or interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or O3 in any downwind state. CAIR establishes budgets for SO2 and NOx for states that significantly contribute or interfere with maintenance and requires such states to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets. EPA is approving the full SIP revision, as interpreted and clarified herein, as fully implementing the CAIR requirements for South Carolina through participation in these cap-and-trade programs. Consequently, this action will also cause the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions by South Carolina sources to be automatically withdrawn. This direct final rule will be effective 11/30/2009, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 11/16/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; indiana; Carbon monoxide maintenance plan updates; Limited maintenance plan
Abstract: The Indiana Department of Environmental Management submitted CO "Limited Maintenance Plan" updates for Lake and Marion Counties on 1/12/2009. These Limited Maintenance Plans demonstrate continued attainment of the CO NAAQS for Lake and Marion counties for an additional 10 yr. EPA is, therefore, approving it into Indiana's SIP. This direct final rule will be effective on 12/14/2009, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 11/16/2009. If adverse comments are received, EPA will publish a timely withdrawal of the direct final rule in the Federal Register informing the public that the rule will not take effect. List of subjects in 40 CFR part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, and intergovernmental relations.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Ohio Administrative Code Rule 3745-21-17 portable fuel containers
Abstract: The Ohio Environmental Protection Agency (Ohio EPA) submitted a revision to its SIP under the Clean Air Act to reduce air pollution in Ohio. The SIP revision consists of a new regulation entitled Ohio's Administrative Code Rule 3745-21-17 "Control of VOC Emissions from Portable Fuel Containers". This rule impacts sale, use, and manufacture of Portable Fuel Containers in the State of Ohio. In this direct final rule, EPA is approving this rule, and will be effective 12/4/2009, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 11/13/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the Arizona State Implementation Plan, Maricopa County Air Quality Department
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Maricopa County Air Quality Department portion of the Arizona SIP. These revisions concern particulate matter emissions and precursors from steam generating units, cogeneration units, stationary gas turbines, process heaters and internal combustion engines. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under CAAA. This rule takes effect on 12/14/2009 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 11/13/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, San Diego Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the San Diego Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from cold solvent cleaning and vapor degreasing operations. EPA is proposing to approve two local rules to regulate these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. Any comments on this proposal must arrive by 11/12/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, San Diego Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the San Diego Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from cold solvent cleaning and vapor degreasing operations. EPA is approving two local rules that regulate these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. This rule is effective on 12/14/2009, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 11/12/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC.

Authors: Committee to Examine the Disposal of Activated Carbon from the Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning Systems at Chemical Agent Disposal Facilities, Board on Army Science and Technology, Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences, National Research Council
Title: The disposal of activated carbon from chemical agent disposal facilities
Source title: The Disposal of Activated Carbon from Chemical Agent Disposal Facilities
Authors with affiliations: Committee to Examine the Disposal of Activated Carbon from the Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning Systems at Chemical Agent Disposal Facilities; Board on Army Science and Technology; Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences; National Research Council
Abstract: For the last two decades, the United States has been destroying its entire stockpile of chemical agents. At the facilities where these agents are being destroyed, effluent gas streams pass through large activated carbon filters before venting to ensure that any residual trace vapors of chemical agents and other pollutants do not escape into the atmosphere in exceedance of regulatory limits. All the carbon will have to be disposed of for final closure of these facilities to take place. In March 2008, the Chemical Materials Agency asked the National Research Council to study, evaluate, and recommend the best methods for proper and safe disposal of the used carbon from the operational disposal facilities. This volume examines various approaches to handling carbon waste streams from the four operating chemical agent disposal facilities. The approaches that will be used at each facility will ultimately be chosen bearing in mind local regulatory practices, facility design and operations, and the characteristics of agent inventories, along with other factors such as public involvement regarding facility operations. © 2009 by the National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Delaware; Regulation to reduce idling of heavy-duty vehicles
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Delaware SIP, which contains a regulation to reduce engine idling time for operation of most heavy-duty vehicles in the state, with certain exceptions. The pollutants reduced by this regulation are VOC and NOx, both of which are ground level ozone pollution precursors. This rule will also reduce emissions of CO, fine particulate matter, and the greenhouse gas CO2. The approval of Delaware?s Regulation No. 45 will strengthen the Delaware SIP and assist the state in meeting and maintaining compliance with air quality standards, including the NAAQS for ground level ozone and fine particulate matter. This rule is effective on 12/7/2009 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse written comment by 11/9/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: OECD report denies existence of carbon leakage, advises against sector subsidies
Abstract: A recent Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) report has denied that unilateral greenhouse gas (GHG) emission cuts will lead to carbon leakage. The report defines carbon leakage as the relocation of manufacturing plants from developed countries that cap and charge GHG emissions, to countries that do not regulate GHG emissions, implying that carbon leakage is not a major threat. OECD says that if energy-intensive industries, including the chemicals sector, are subsidized in a bid to avoid potential carbon leakage, the cost to the rest of the world of reducing GHG emissions would rise 50%. The EU is due to decide by the end of this year whether to exempt industries from significant emissions trading scheme charges because of the threat of carbon leakage. The EU heads of state and the European Parliament have well understood the threat of a unilateral burden to their energy-intensive sectors.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer continental shelf air regulations consistency update for New Jersey
Abstract: EPA is proposing to update a portion of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of states' seaward boundaries which must be promulgated into the regulations and updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area, as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the Clean Air Act. The portion of the OCS air regulations that is being updated pertains to the requirements for OCS sources in the State of New Jersey. The intended effect of approving the OCS requirements for the State of New Jersey is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. The requirements discussed are proposed to be incorporated by reference into the Code of Federal Regulations and are listed in the appendix to the OCS air regulations. Comments must be received on or before 11/2/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 55 include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedures, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NO2, NOx, SOx, outer continental shelf, ozone, particulate matter, permits, reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans: Alabama: Proposed approval of revisions to the visible emissions rule and alternative proposed disapproval of revisions to the visible emissions rule
Abstract: On 4/3/2009, EPA granted a 2/25/2009, petition seeking reconsideration of an 10/15/2008, final action approving a SIP revision regarding the State of Alabama's visible emissions rules. As part of its reconsideration process, EPA is now proposing to either affirm the previous rulemaking (which approved the revisions) or, alternatively, amend its previous rulemaking (i.e., disapproving the revisions). EPA is seeking public comment on the issues raised in the petition for reconsideration as well as the actions proposed in this notice. EPA is also seeking public comment on the relationship between opacity and particulate matter mass emissions. Following its evaluation of the issues raised in the petition for reconsideration, and any information submitted during the public comment process, EPA will take final action either affirming the previous rulemaking or amending the previous rulemaking and disapproving the revisions to the visible emissions portion of Alabama's SIP. Comments must be received on or before 11/16/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, lead, nitrogen dioxide, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, sulfur oxides, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Processing - Quick takes: Siberian gas plant expansion starts up
Abstract: Sibur LLC has announced the start-up of the second stage of its expansion at the Yuzhno-Balyksky gas processing plant in the Tyumen region. The plant handles a hydrocarbon feed associated with crude oil production (called "associated petroleum gas") which it separates into natural gas, NGL, and napthas. Its expansion doubles inlet capacity to 3 billion cu m/yr and pushes Sibur?s company-wide gas processing capacity to 19 billion cu m/yr. The plant is designed to produce 2.8 billion cu m/yr of dry gas and 900,000 ton/yr of light hydrocarbons.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Determination of attainment, approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Indiana
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve the SIP revision submitted by Pennsylvania on 5/23/2008. EPA is also proposing to approve revisions that address NOx ozone season emission reduction requirements for internal combustion engines and cement kilns statewide, and small sources of NOx in the five counties (Chicago-Gary-Lake County, Illinois-Indiana) that comprise the Pennsylvania portion of the Philadelphia 8-hr ozone nonattainment area. This action proposes to approve the State's request for a waiver from the NOx RACT requirements for Lake and Porter Counties under the CAA. EPA is deferring the imposition of sanctions for the State's failure to submit required NOx RACT regulations. Comments must be received on or before 10/26/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans, Alabama: Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a portion of the SIP revision submitted by the State of Alabama, through the Alabama Department of Environmental Management (ADEM), on 3/7/2007. This action proposes to approve the portion of the 3/7/2007 submittal that addresses State reporting requirements under the NOx SIP Call and the Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) found in 40 CFR 51.122 and 51.125 as amended by the CAIR rulemakings. Specifically, in this action, EPA is proposing to approve revisions to Chapter 335-3-1 "General Provisions". EPA is continuing to approve CAIR provisions into SIP as appropriate. CAIR, as promulgated, requires States to reduce SO2 and NOx emissions that significantly contribute to, or interfere with maintenance of, NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. CAIR establishes budgets for SO2 and NOx for States that contribute significantly to nonattainment in downwind States and requires the significantly contributing States to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets. States have the flexibility to choose which control measures to adopt to achieve the budgets, including participation in EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx O3 season emissions. This action is being taken pursuant to section 110 of the Clean Air Act (CAA). Written comments must be received on or before 10/23/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Transportation - Quick takes: Licenses push Gorgon LNG towards reality
Abstract: Chevron Corp's Gorgon project, including a planned three-train, 15 million-ton/yr LNG plant, took another step to realization on 9/1/2009 when Australia's resources and energy minister and Western Australia's state petroleum minister revealed they had offered to the Gorgon partnership five production licenses to cover Io-Jansz and Gorgon gas fields that will back stop the project. Partners for the $42 billion project are Chevron 50%, ExxonMobil Corp 25%, and Royal Dutch Shell PLC 25%. The offshore gas fields that are the subject of the licenses will be developed via subsea wells and two pipelines bringing gas to Barrow Island where three LNG trains will each produce 5 million ton/yr. There will also be a 300-Tj/day domestic gas plant feeding into a pipeline to the mainland and a CO2 sequestration plant that can store in deep formations beneath the island the high levels of CO2 from Gorgon fields. Chevron expects to make a final investment decision soon.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Adequacy status of the Metropolitan Washington DC Area (DC-MD-VA) area 8-hour ozone non-attainment area's reasonable further progress plan vehicle emission budgets for transportation conformity purposes
Abstract: EPA have found the Motor Vehicle Emissions Budgets (MVEB) in the 2008 Reasonable Further Progress Plan, submitted on 6/4/2007, by the Maryland Department of the Environment and on 6/12/2007 by the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality and the District of Columbia Department of the Environment are adequate for transportation conformity purposes. As a result of EPA's finding, the Metropolitan Washington, DC, area must use the MVEB from the 2008 RFP Plan for future conformity determinations for the 8-hr ozone standard. These MVEB are effective on 9/21/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: CH2M Hill awarded CO 2 pipeline project
Abstract: On 9/29/2009, CH2M HILL was awarded an engineering, procurement, and construction management contract from Encore Acquisition Co for its Greencore Project - a new 230-mi, high pressure CO 2 pipeline. The project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by capturing CO 2 emissions from the Lost Cabin Gas Plant in Fremont County, WY. Captured CO 2 will be injected into oil wells in Encore's Bell Creek Field in southeastern Montana and will help increase domestic oil production from that field. By capturing CO 2 that would otherwise be released into the atmosphere, this project will reduce CO 2 emissions by ≈ 1 million ton/yr. It is estimated that the CO 2 injection project will increase oil production from existing wells from 1200 bpd to a peak response of 7000 bpd. CH2M HILL will design and construct a 230-mi, combination 8- and 10-in. dia pipeline to transfer the compressed CO 2 from the Lost Cabin Plant in Wyoming to wells throughout the 21,000-acre Bell Creek Field in southeastern Montana. Initiated in August 2009, the Greencore CO 2 Pipeline project is expected to be in place and operational in 2011.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Report: ASCOPE feature: Singapore: No reserves, no problem
Abstract: A discussion on Singapore's oil and gas industry covers the strategy taken by Singapore to carve a niche in the industry despite the lack of natural resources; correlation between Singapore's future growth and overcoming resource limitations; background information on the Singapore Petroleum Co; oil consumption from 1995 to 2005; natural gas consumption from 1990 to 2004; exploration and production developments; downstream activities, e.g., crude oil refining capacity; expansion of Singapore's independent storage facilities due to a shortage of oil storage space; demand for imports of refined products; petroleum refining developments, e.g., ExxonMobil's plans to build another ethylene cracker; increase in natural gas use in Singapore due to the government's policies aimed at reducing CO2 and sulfur emissions to ensure energy security and promote the country as a regional hub for an integrated gas pipeline network; SembGas' agreement to purchase West Natuna natural gas via pipelines; and Singapore's plans to build an LNG import terminal.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Breakthroughs in technology for manufacture of syngas via reforming of methane with CO2
Source title: China Petroleum Processing and Petrochemical Technology
Abstract: The pilot project for the manufacture of synthesis gas (syngas) via methane reforming CO2 had recently passed the experts' appraisal organized by the Shandong Provincial Science and Technology Department. The key technique aimed at application of natural gas chemicals has its innovative nature with the overall technology reaching the internationally advanced level. The successful development of this project could reduce greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions to protect the environment. This project could also provide feedstocks for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and hydroformylation reaction, which can avoid the disadvantage of high H/C ratio characteristic of the commercial process for methane reforming in the presence of steam. Compared to air and steam as the oxygen sources, the reaction was mild when using CO2 as the oxygen source, and the reaction could be controlled more easily. This project has innovatively synthesized the mesoporous nano-ZrO2 with high specific surface area and concentrated pore distribution by adopting the solid reaction structural guiding method and alcohol heating method. To synthesize the mesoporous Al2O3 with specific surface area and pore diameter, glucose and sugar were first used as the structure guiding agent. Pilot tests showed that the novel catalyst has higher metal dispersion with excellent catalytic activity and chemical stability. The catalysts synthesized on the basis of two mesoporous materials could have good potentials in application.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, Antelope Valley Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the Antelope Valley Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from leaking components at industrial facilities, e.g., petroleum refineries and chemical manufacturing plants. EPA is proposing to approve a local rule to regulate these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. At the same time, it is also approving a Negative Declaration and removing rules from the SIP. Any comments on this proposal must arrive by 9/28/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, Antelope Valley Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Antelope Valley Air Quality Management District (AVAQMD) portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from leaking components at facilities, e.g., oil refineries and chemical manufacturing plants. EPA is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. At the same time, EPA is also approving an AVAQMD Negative Declaration and removing rules from the SIP. This rule is effective on 10/27/2009, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 9/28/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is proposing a limited approval and limited disapproval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern a local fee rule that applies to major sources of VOC and NOx emissions within the San Joaquin Valley ozone nonattainment area. EPA is proposing action on a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the CAAA. EPA is taking comments on this proposal and plan to follow with a final action. Any comments must be received by 9/18/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Implementation of the 1997 8-Hour Ozone National Ambient Air Quality Standard: Addressing a portion of the phase 2 ozone implementation rule concerning reasonable further progress emissions reductions credits outside ozone nonattainment areas
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to revise a portion of its Phase 2 implementation rule for the 8-hr ozone NAAQS. EPA had sought a voluntary remand from the US Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and the Court granted EPA's request. This rule addresses an interpretation allowing certain credits toward reasonable further progress for the 8-hr standard from emissions reductions outside the nonattainment area. Entities potentially affected directly by this action include state, local, and tribal governments. Entities potentially affected indirectly by this rule include owners and operators of sources of emissions, i.e., VOC, NOx, that contribute to ground-level ozone concentrations. This rule is effective on 10/13/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; North Carolina; Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the North Carolina SIP submitted by the State of North Carolina through the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources on 6/20/2008. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR). CAIR, as promulgated, requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, or interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. In the full SIP revision that EPA is proposing to approve, North Carolina will meet CAIR requirements by participating in cap-and-trade programs. Consequently, this action will also cause the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans concerning SO2, NOx, annual, and NOx ozone season emissions by North Carolina sources to be automatically withdrawn. Comments must be received on or before 9/8/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, electric utilities, intergovernmental relations, CO, NOx, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and SO2. Subjects in 40 CFR Part 96 include environmental protection, air pollution control, electric utilities, intergovernmental relations, NOx, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and SO2.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of maintenance plan for carbon monoxide; State of Arizona; Tucson air planning area
Abstract: Pursuant to the Clean Air Act, EPA is proposing to approve two SIP plan revisions submitted by the State of Arizona. The State submitted the 2008 Revision to the Carbon Monoxide Limited Maintenance Plan for the Tucson Air Planning Area on 7/10/2008. EPA is proposing to approve the 2008 Limited Maintenance Plan because it provides for the maintenance of the CO NAAQS within the Tucson Air Planning Area through the second 10-yr portion of the maintenance period. EPA is also proposing to approve a statutory provision that was submitted by the State on 6/22/2009 as a revision to the SIP and that extends the life of the State's vehicle emissions inspection program through the end of 2016. EPA is taking this action pursuant to those provisions of the Clean Air Act that obligate the Agency to take action on submittals of revisions to SIP. The effect of this action would be to make certain commitments related to maintenance of the CO standard in the Tucson Air Planning Area Federally enforceable as part of the Arizona SIP. Written comments must be received at the address below on or before 9/4/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, intergovernmental relations, and reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; West Virginia; Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of West Virginia. This revision establishes budget trading programs for NOx annual, NOx ozone season, and SO2 annual emissions to address the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), and recodifies and revises provisions pertaining to internal combustion engines and cement kilns that are subject to the NOx SIP Call. West Virginia will meet its CAIR requirements by participating in the EPA-administered regional cap-and-trade program for NOx annual, NOx ozone season, and SO2 annual emissions. EPA is determining that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for West Virginia. CAIR, as promulgated, requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, or interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind State. CAIR establishes budgets for SO2 and NOx for States that contribute significantly to nonattainment in downwind States and requires the significantly contributing States to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets. In the SIP revision that EPA is approving, West Virginia will meet CAIR requirements by participating in these cap-and-trade programs. The final rule is effective on 8/4/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Enbridge gets permit for U.S.-Canada pipeline
Abstract: On 8/20/2009, the US State department issued a permit allowing the Alberta Clipper pipeline to be constructed between Alberta's oil sands and Minnesota. Enbridge's proposed pipeline drew protests from environmental advocates, since the pipeline will increase the amount of crude oil flowing from Canada to the US and the greater refining costs of oil sands resources contribute to greenhouse gas buildup. However, the State Department contends reductions in carbon emissions are better handled through domestic policy, rather than reductions in supply.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: ADB drives integration with hydro
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Abstract: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is promoting power sector integration utilizing hydro schemes to promote economic integration across Asia. The new ADB energy strategy, which was set up in June, aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by promoting low carbon power projects. Industrial centers in both India and Pakistan are demanding increased electricity supplies, while the mountainous north of the subcontinent has vast hydro potential that could be tapped. South Asia could also benefit from another of the ADB's pet projects. The government of Ukraine has held talks with Tajik officials this year on investing in the Rogun project. While the original construction works will be of some benefit, a number of existing tunnels must be backfilled and sealed with concrete plugs. The MRC has also made some progress in reaching resource cooperation agreements with upstream states China and Myanmar.
Index Keywords: Asian Development Bank; Construction works; Cooperation agreement; Economic integration; Electricity supply; Energy strategy; Existing tunnel; Low carbon; Myanmars; Pakistan; Power projects; Power sector; South Asia; Ukraine; Energy management; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Leakage (fluid); Gas emissions; Asian Development Bank; economic integration; electricity supply; emission control; energy planning; greenhouse gas; hydroelectric power; strategic approach; China; India; Myanmar; Pakistan; Ukraine

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: World news: USA: New digest: India: Challenges ahead
Abstract: Carl Hughes, Lead Partner for Deloitte's UK Energy practice, spoke at the Petroleum Federation of India conference in New Delhi in June 2009 on key challenges for the oil and gas industry. According to Hughes, producing and consuming countries should not take the oil and gas industry for granted. Depending on the outcomes of the Copenhagen climate conference later in 2009, significantly more governmental activity around regulating petroleum related carbon emissions might be seen. One recent example of such activity is the new complex rule passed in the State of California regulating the greenhouse emissions from cars and trucks. This is expected to cut the state's gasoline consumption by 25% in the next decade by increasing the number of electric and hydrogen fueled cars.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; Control of emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx)
Abstract: The EPA is taking a direct final action to approve revisions to the Texas SIP. It is approving revisions to 30 TAC Chapter 117, Control of Air Pollution from Nitrogen Compounds, that the State submitted on 3/10/2009. These revisions amend the Beaumont-Port Arthur 8-Hr Ozone Nonattainment Area Major Source rules, the Houston-Galveston-Brazoria (HGB) 8-Hr Ozone Nonattainment Area Major Source rules, and the HGB 8-Hr Ozone Nonattainment Area Minor Source rules. These revisions add flexibility and consistency to the current stationary reciprocating internal combustion engine and gas turbine monitoring specifications found in Chapter 117 by allowing for an additional option for monitoring NOx emissions. These revisions are consistent with the Clean Air Act (CAA). Therefore, EPA is approving these revisions pursuant to section 110 of the CAA. This direct final rule will be effective on 9/29/2009 without further notice unless EPA receives relevant adverse comments by 8/31/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, nitrogen oxide, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, ozone, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, San Joaquin Valley air pollution control district
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions were proposed in the Federal Register on 6/8/2009 and concern VOC emissions from organic solvent cleaning and degreasing operations. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 8/31/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Agency information collection activities; Submission to OMB for review and approval; Comment request; Inclusion of Delaware and New Jersey in the clean air interstate rule (renewal); EPA ICR no. 2184.03, OMB control No. 2060-0584
Abstract: In compliance with the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) (44 U.S.C. 3501 et seq.), this document announces that an Information Collection Request (ICR) was forwarded to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) for review and approval. This is a request to renew an existing approved collection. The ICR describes the nature of the information collection and its estimated burden and cost. In this ICR, EPA promulgated a rule to add the States of Delaware and New Jersey to the States that are subject to the Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) because of their PM2.5 impact on other States and to require that Delaware and New Jersey report all of the emissions-related data required by CAIR. These emissions data reporting requirements include reporting requirements and combine these reporting requirements with existing requirements from the Consolidated Emissions Reporting Rule, the Emission Reporting Requirements for Ozone SIP Revisions Relating to Statewide Budgets for NOx Emissions to Reduce Regional Transport of Ozone (NOx SIP Call), the Acid Rain Program under Title IV of the CAA Amendments of 1990, and the Rule to Reduce Interstate Transport of Fine Particulate Matter and Ozone (Clean Air Interstate Rule, CAIR). Each of these four existing requirements has an approved ICR in place. Additional comments may be submitted on or before 8/28/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Agency information collection activities; Submission to OMB for review and approval; Comment request; Consolidated emissions reporting rule (renewal); EPA ICR No. 0916.13, OMB control No. 2060-0088
Abstract: In compliance with the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) (44 U.S.C. 3501 et seq.), this document announces that an Information Collection Request (ICR) was forwarded to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) for review and approval. This is a request to renew an existing approved collection. The ICR describes the nature of the information collection and its estimated burden and cost. In this ICR, EPA has promulgated a Consolidated Emissions Reporting Rule (CERR) (40 CFR part 51, subpart A) to coordinate new emissions inventory reporting requirements with existing requirements of the CAAA. Under the CERR, 55 state and territorial air quality agencies, including the District of Columbia (DC), as well as an estimated 49 local air quality agencies, must annually submit emissions data for point sources emitting specified levels of VOC, NOx, CO, SO2, PM10, PM2.5, and NH3. Every 3 yr, states are required to submit a point source inventory, as well as a statewide stationary non-point, non-road mobile, onroad mobile, and biogenic source inventory for all criteria pollutants (including lead and lead compounds) and their precursors. Additional comments may be submitted on or before 8/28/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, San Joaquin Valley air pollution control district
Abstract: EPA is proposing a limited approval and limited disapproval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from steam-enhanced crude oil production well vents, aerospace coating operations, and polyester resin operations. EPA is proposing action on local rules that regulate these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. It is taking comments on this proposal and plan to follow with a final action. DATES: Any comments must arrive by 8/17/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans: 1-hour ozone extreme area plan for San Joaquin Valley, CA
Abstract: EPA proposes to approve in part and disapprove in part SIP revisions submitted by the State of California to meet the Clean Air Act (CAA) requirements applicable to the San Joaquin Valley, CA, 1-hr ozone nonattainment area (SJV area). These requirements apply to the SJV area following its 4/16/2004 reclassification from severe to extreme for the 1-hr ozone NAAQS. EPA is proposing to approve the SIP revisions for the SJV area as meeting applicable CAA requirements for the attainment demonstration, rate-of-progress demonstration and related contingency measures, and other control measures. EPA is also proposing to disapprove the contingency measures for failure to attain and to approve the SJV Air Pollution Control District?s Rule 9310, "School Bus Fleets". Comments for this proposed rule must be submitted by 8/13/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, San Joaquin Valley unified air pollution control district
Abstract: EPA is proposing a limited approval and limited disapproval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern a local fee rule that applies to major sources of VOC and NOx compound and NO emissions within the San Joaquin Valley ozone nonattainment area. EPA is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the CAAA. EPA is taking comments on this proposal, which must be received by 8/13/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, Northern Sierra air quality management district and San Joaquin Valley unified air pollution control district
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the Northern Sierra Air Quality Management District and San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portions of the California SIP. Under authority of the CAAA, EPA is proposing to approve local rules that address VOC emissions from asphalt paving, gasoline bulk storage tanks, and gasoline dispensing stations. Any comments must arrive by 8/12/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Pennsylvania; Allegheny County, continuous opacity monitor regulation
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Pennsylvania SIP. This SIP revision, "Revision 58, Continuous Opacity Monitor Regulation Changes," consists of changes to the Allegheny County Health Department (ACHD) Rules and Regulations, Article XXI, Air Pollution Control. EPA is approving this revision to the Pennsylvania SIP in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act. The subjects listed in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, NO2, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and SOx. This rule is effective on 9/11/2009 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse written comment by 8/12/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Virginia; Update to materials incorporated by reference
Abstract: EPA is updating the materials submitted by Virginia that are incorporated by reference into the SIP. The regulations affected by this update were previously submitted by the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality and approved by EPA. This update affects the SIP materials that are available for public inspection at the National Archives and Records Administration, the Air and Radiation Docket and Information Center located at EPA Headquarters in Washington, DC, and the Regional Office. The EPA-approved Virginia regulations and statuses include emission standards for petroleum liquid storage and transfer operations (Rule 4-37); emission standards for mobile sources; regulations for the control of motor vehicle emissions in the Northern Virginia area; and regulation governing the oxygenation of gasoline. This action is effective on 7/13/2009.

Authors: National Research Council, Division of Behavioral and Social Sciences and Education, Committee on the Human Dimensions of Global Change, Panel on Strategies and Methods for Climate-Related Decision Support
Title: Informing Decisions in a Changing Climate
Source title: Informing Decisions in a Changing Climate
Authors with affiliations: National Research Council; Division of Behavioral and Social Sciences and Education; Committee on the Human Dimensions of Global Change; Panel on Strategies and Methods for Climate-Related Decision Support
Abstract: Everyone--government agencies, private organizations, and individuals--is facing a changing climate: an environment in which it is no longer prudent to follow routines based on past climatic averages. State and local agencies in particular, as well as the federal government, need to consider what they will have to do differently if the 100-year flood arrives every decade or so, if the protected areas for threatened species are no longer habitable, or if a region can expect more frequent and more severe wildfires, hurricanes, droughts, water shortages, or other extreme environmental events. Both conceptually and practically, people and organizations will have to adjust what may be life-long assumptions to meet the potential consequences of climate change. How and where should bridges be built? What zoning rules may need to be changed? How can targets for reduced carbon emissions be met? These and myriad other questions will need to be answered in the coming years and decades. Informing Decisions in a Changing Climate examines the growing need for climate-related decision support--that is, organized efforts to produce, disseminate, and facilitate the use of data and information in order to improve the quality and efficacy of climate-related decisions. Drawing on evidence from past efforts to organize science for improved decision making, it develops guidance for government agencies and other institutions that will provide or use information for coping with climate change. This volume provides critical analysis of interest to agencies at every level, as well as private organizations that will have to cope with the world's changing climate. © 2009 by the National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Research and development: MOL Technology to move
Abstract: Mitsui O.S.K. Lines Ltd plans to move its MOL Technology Research Centre from its current site in Nishikojiya, Ota Ward, Tokyo, to Aso Ward in Kawasald, Kanagawa Prefecture. The MOL Technology Research Centre has taken a proactive approach to analyzing vessel fuel oils and lubricants, developing a fuel oil pre-treatment device, research and development on CO2 reduction, and other R&D efforts to improve storage and transport technologies. The new center will be an environmentally-friendly research facility using energy-saving technologies such as solar energy, natural lighting, and an ice thermal storage system, using electricity to make ice at night, when demand for power is low, and then melting the ice for air conditioning.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Green shoots
Abstract: West Midlands Fire Service (WMFS), England is adopting a range of strategic measures to encourage environmental sustainability. It has taken certain steps based on research to solve the problem of greenhouse gas production from its building stock and vehicle fleet, while making efforts to reduce the emissions from fire incidents. Its integrated risk management team continuously compares the volume of carbon dioxide (CO2) released from fire incidents within its area over a long period of time. The efforts of WMFS have resulted in significant reduction in CO2 across the investigated period along with the number of dwelling fire incidents. These improvements have been possible through significant community safety education efforts and prevention activities. WMFS is also involved in significant research efforts to identify the relationship between certain types of service demand during hot weather conditions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: €4b injection for European energy projects
Abstract: The European Commission (EC) is offering $5.6 billion to developers of carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, offshore wind energy, and gas and electricity infrastructure. Under the European Energy Programme for Recovery, developers have until 7/15/2009 to submit proposals, and the EC expects to begin handing out the first of the funds to successful applicants by the end of the year. The financing will speed up investments in the energy sector and have a direct impact on the EU economy and on employment. It will also help to improve the security of supply of the most vulnerable member states. The funding will also assist in speeding up the implementation of the 20/20/20 objectives (to reduce carbon emissions and energy consumption by 20%, and increase renewable energy use by 20%, all by 2020) by promoting for the first time on a large scale the development of CCS technologies and the implementation of high power wind turbines.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Biomass cofiring: Another way to clean your coal
Abstract: Demand for renewable power is burgeoning as state governments impose increasingly rigorous environmental and procurement standards on the energy industry. Biomass cofiring has yet to attract much attention, even though it could help many utilities meet their renewable portfolio requirements, reduce carbon emissions, and solve other regional environmental problems. A discussion on biomass cofiring covers field tests; cofiring biomass in US coal-fired boilers as a serious option for reducing carbon emissions and as a strategy for meeting a renewable portfolio standard; retrofitting of central station coal-fired plants; carbon lifecycle and energy balance when cofiring biomass with coal; biomass that may be utilized to cofire coal-fired generators; cofiring technologies available for use with specific boilers; cost issues; and incentives for cofiring.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Power digest: Masdar connects 10-MW PV plant to Abu Dhabi grid
Abstract: Enviromena Power System on June 1 announced the completion of the Masdar 10-Mw Solar Power Plant, the largest grid-connected solar system in the Middle East and North Africa. The 212,000 sq m solar system consists of 87,777 photovoltaic modules and will produce 17,500 Mw-hr of clean energy each year, offsetting ∼ 15,000 ton/yr of carbon emissions. The plant will produce energy to power the initial construction activities of Masdar City. It is also one of the most quickly constructed and cost-efficient photovoltaic installations in the world in terms of projected power output.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environews: Cutting carbon emissions in half
Abstract: Seattle Steam was ready to fire up its boilers and reduce the carbon footprint of 200 downtown Seattle buildings. The company provides energy for heating these facilities. The city has taken on a goal of meeting the Kyoto Protocol goals and this will be a big step in that direction. The conversion project took a year to achieve and company officials hope the use of the biomass will be much more stable in price than the wildly fluctuating natural gas prices. About $5 million that was spent on natural gas supplied from outside sources will now be spent to purchase waste wood from local suppliers. The ash (∼ 250 ton/day) from the burned material will be recycled into a variety of locally manufactured goods. By converting to this naturally renewable resource, the company is reducing its CO2 equivalent (C02e) output by nearly 45,000 ton/yr. It is calculated by converting the other 5 greenhouse gases to CO2 for reporting purposes.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Petroleum Economist: Asia and Australasia: Australia: the Western Australia...
Abstract: The Western Australia state government granted environmental approval for the $50 billion, 40 tcf Gorgon LNG project in August 2009. The national government and the Western Australian state government agreed to accept joint liability for storing CO2 from the scheme also in August 2009. The national government must now finalize its own environmental approval process. The project partners are expected to take a final investment decision in 2009 and first LNG supplies may become available as soon as 2014. Shareholders are Chevron (50% and operator), Shell (25%), and ExxonMobil (25%).

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Middle East: Kuwait: Parliament will debate...
Abstract: Kuwait's Parliament will debate before mid-July 2009 a new 5-yr development program for the oil and gas sector. A new Supreme Petroleum Council (SPC) will also be appointed in to inject more momentum into essential oil and gas projects. The SPC is responsible for approving all government policy and expenditure related to the hydrocarbons sector. The new plan may extend the timeline for expanding crude production capacity and put more emphasis on developing the country's gas reserves. Present plans call for producing 4 million bpd by 2020, up from around 3 million bpd. However, this deadline may be put back to 2030.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Asia: China approves inland AP1000s
Abstract: China has begun clearing space inland for the construction of 3 new AP1000 nuclear power plants. The units will be the first to be built independently by Chinese companies and away from the coast. China wants to bring nuclear power inland to reduce its carbon footprint and end regional power shortages. Initially, 2 reactors will be built at sites in Taohuajiang City in Hunan Province by CNN, Xian'ning City in Hubei Province by China Guangdong Nuclear, and Pengze City in Jiangxi Province by China Power Investment. Another phase of construction will follow and it is expected that each site will eventually hold 4 reactors in total. Currently, its installed capacity generates around 9 Gw of nuclear power. The country expects this to rise to around 60 Gw by 2020, and as much as 160 Gw by 2030.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: Dow sales rolls on
Abstract: To slim down its debt, Dow Chemical has agreed to sell its calcium chloride business and its stake in a Netherlands-based oil refinery for $900 million. The calcium chloride business has been sold to Occidental Petroleum for more than $210 million. The deal includes 130 staff and the calcium chloride assets associated with Dow's Ludington operations in Michigan. In the second transaction, Dow is divesting its 45% stake in crude oil refinery Total Raffinaderij Nederland to Lukoil for an estimated $725 million. The 400 jobs at the Zeeland region outfit will remain safe in the short term and expects the deal to close in the third quarter of 2009. Meanwhile, Dow is busy landing new projects and expanding its core businesses. The Ras Tanura oil refinery and petrochemicals complex, a planned joint venture between Dow Chemical and Saudi Aramco, may be back on track. The companies plan to expand Aramco's Ras Tanura refinery by 400,000 bpd to over 600,000 bpd, accompanied by a new petrochemicals complex next door. The companies have just renewed their call on contractors to tender for the project. Dow also signed a separate deal with Gazprom to reduce the Russian firm's greenhouse gas emissions. The deal will see Dow install process improvements and greener technologies at Gazprom sites around the world in return for access to carbon credits to offset its own emissions.
